doc.abstracts: On June 8, 1992 Alden Winship Clausen was interviewed by the Brookings Institution on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by John Lewis, Richard Webb, and Devesh Kapur. During his tenure at the World Bank Group, Mr. Clausen served as its sixth President from 1981 to 1986. His transcript concerns his presidency. When he assumed office, the international economy was deep into one of the worst recessions of the post-World War II era. For Clausen the solution to continue development work in a troubled international economy was to emphasize the role of free markets, private flows of capital and international cooperation, together with his commercial banker's knowledge of finance, inspired innovations concerning investment guarantees and cofinancing with commercial banks. He championed increased structural and sectoral lending and expanded aid coordination.
